channel.title: NYT > Top Stories
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Like Trump, U.S. Embassies Are Raising Cash for Lavish July Fourth Parties
item.description: Some of Washington’s diplomatic outposts in Asia are raising millions for events to mark the 250th independence anniversary. One ambassador offered to sing and dance.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Stevenson, River Akira Davis and Kenneth P. Vogel
item.media:credit: Heather Diehl/Getty Images
item.media:description: The Washington Monument illuminated on New Year’s Eve. In December, President Trump announced a campaign to organize celebrations of America’s 250th birthday.

item.title: Trump’s Relentless Self-Promotion Fosters an American Cult of Personality
item.description: President Trump has engaged in a spree of self-aggrandizement unlike any of his predecessors, fostering a mythologized superhuman persona and making himself the inescapable force at home and around the world.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: “Don Colossus” — a 15-foot bronze statue of President Trump — at the sculptor’s studio in Zanesville, Ohio, earlier this month.

item.title: Canada Gives U.S. Arms Makers the Cold Shoulder on Military Spending
item.description: Canada plans to unveil a new strategy that will shift its current reliance on American companies to Canadian military suppliers.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Spencer Colby/The Canadian Press, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Prime Minister Mark Carney in Ottawa, Canada, on Wednesday.

item.title: Trump Administration Ends Credit for Start-Stop Feature in Cars
item.description: Manufacturers will no longer get a credit toward vehicle emissions standards by installing engines that automatically stop at red lights.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Holpuch
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Complaints to the U.S. Department of Transportation about the start-stop feature peaked in 2022 and fell almost in half by 2024.

item.title: Three American Speeches at Munich, and Plenty of Confusion
item.description: As the U.S. message veered from shared heritage and values to shared interests and back again, Europeans wondered what kind of alliance they were left with.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alex Brandon
item.media:description: Secretary of State Marco Rubio on Sunday in Budapest, Hungary, where he traveled after addressing the Munich Security Conference.

item.title: In Munich, Lawmakers Concede Scars Remain After Trump’s Greenland Threat
item.description: Congress members said that President Trump’s coveting of Greenland had left a mark, even as they expressed hope for a less bellicose approach to foreign relations.
item.dc:creator: Megan Mineiro
item.media:credit: Tierney L. Cross/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump’s statements on Greenland loomed large at Munich Security Conference, though top lawmakers said his threat to take the territory was “put to bed.”

item.title: Trump’s Stinging Attack on Israel’s President Touches a Nerve
item.description: President Trump called President Isaac Herzog of Israel “disgraceful” because he has not yet pardoned Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu in his corruption trial.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump with Israel’s president, Isaac Herzog, and Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu at Ben Gurion Airport in October.

item.title: Warner Bros. Is Said to Consider Reopening Talks With Paramount
item.description: Warner Bros. Discovery had agreed to sell itself to Netflix, but its contract allows it to pursue offers that may lead to a superior deal.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Hirsch
item.media:credit: Aleksey Kondratyev for The New York Times
item.media:description: Warner Bros. Discovery has until Feb. 25 to respond to Paramount’s latest proposal.

item.title: In Xi Jinping’s Purge of the Military, a Search for Absolute Loyalty
item.description: By reaching back to Maoist tactics of “rectification,” the Chinese leader is signaling that control over the gun requires a state of perpetual cleansing.
item.dc:creator: Lily Kuo
item.media:credit: Florence Lo/Reuters
item.media:description: President Xi Jinping of China at a ceremony with members of the Chinese People’s Liberation Army last year. Over the past two years, Mr. Xi has removed five of the six generals in China’s top military body.

item.title: Cortina’s 70-Year-Old Curling Stadium Is a Star at the Winter Olympics
item.description: It hosted Olympic hockey in 1956 and James Bond a quarter-century later. Cortina’s beloved Olympic Stadium is now bursting with excitement for curling.
item.dc:creator: Heather Knight
item.media:credit: James Hill for The New York Times
item.media:description: The roof of the at the Olympic Stadium in Cortina d’Ampezzo, which is hosting the 2026 Games with Milan.

item.title: Republican State Legislators Rush to Limit Their Own Regulators
item.description: South Carolina’s state legislature is one of 17, mainly in heavily Republican states, that is moving to handcuff state agencies at a moment of tectonic changes in energy, technology and finance.
item.dc:creator: David W. Chen and Tierney L. Cross
item.media:description: Some business owners like Gail Nicholls, owner of Red Bug Barn, a pet supply store in Richburg, S.C., support deregulation. Ms. Nicholls spends hours each week applying for permits.

item.title: What to Know About the Homeland Security Shutdown
item.description: Funding for the Department of Homeland Security lapsed on Saturday amid a standoff over restrictions that Democrats have demanded for federal immigration agents. But much of its work continues.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Customs and Border Protection agents stopping vehicles in Minneapolis in January.

item.title: Winter Storms Could Bring 8 Feet of Snow to Parts of California
item.description: The greatest impact is expected across Northern California, where a pair of powerful storms are expected to begin on Sunday night and last into the week.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Light Snowfall Coming to New York, New Jersey and Long Island
item.description: Forecasters said snowfall totals of one to two inches were likely Sunday night, with isolated amounts of up to three inches across New York City, northeastern New Jersey and much of Long Island.
item.dc:creator: Nazaneen Ghaffar and Johnny Diaz
item.media:credit: Todd Heisler/The New York Times
item.media:description: In Woodside, Queens, where snow is still piled in the streets from earlier storms. Forecasters are predicting up to two more inches of snow, with isolated amounts of up to three inches, across New York City from Sunday into Monday.

item.title: Diplomatic Feud With China Weighs on Japan’s Economy
item.description: A standoff over the security of Taiwan has led to a steep decline in the number of Chinese visitors to Japan, which is heavily dependent on the tourists.
item.dc:creator: River Akira Davis
item.media:credit: Greg Baker/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A Chinese tour group in Tokyo last year. A decline in visitors has followed remarks by the Japanese prime minister suggesting Japan would come to Taiwan’s defense in the event of a Chinese invasion.

item.title: How A.I. Salaries Are Causing Couples to Rethink Money in Relationships
item.description: The artificial intelligence frenzy is creating personal fortunes rarely seen in modern technology and changing people’s attitudes about fairness and money in relationships.
item.dc:creator: Kami Rieck
item.media:credit: Ian C. Bates for The New York Times
item.media:description: Akash Samant is a co-founder of Coverflow, an A.I. start-up that serves insurance agencies. He hopes to make enough money from his company going public or being acquired to give his girlfriend the choice to opt out of working.

item.title: Tax Missteps Happen — Even When Two Financial Pros are Married
item.description: You’d think a financial planner married to another financial planner would have it easy come tax time. Alas, no.
item.dc:creator: Ron Lieber
item.media:credit: Celeste Noche for The New York Times
item.media:description: Natalie and Dan Slagle run Fyooz Financial Planning together. One tax mistake they made was using money from an I.R.A. to pay taxes while converting it to a Roth, which resulted in a penalty.

item.title: On the Las Vegas Strip, Local Acts at Delilah and Elsewhere Set the Vibe
item.description: On the Strip and beyond, clubs, bars and restaurants spotlight local performers who deliver some of the city’s best entertainment.
item.dc:creator: Alex Schechter and Tag Christof

item.title: 2025 Film Independent Spirit Awards: Complete Winners List
item.description: Here’s who went home with an Indie Spirit Award on Sunday.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Kevin Winter/Getty Images
item.media:description: Eva Victor won the Best Screenplay award for her film “Sorry, Baby.”

item.title: See the Looks From the 2026 Film Independent Spirit Awards
item.description: The awards show, which celebrates independent film and television, moved back to the Hollywood Palladium for this year’s awards show.
item.dc:creator: The Styles Desk
item.media:credit: Jordan Strauss/Invision, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Rose Byrne, winner for Best Lead Performance for “If I Had Legs I’d Kick You.”

item.title: Ro Khanna Is Shaken by What He’s Learned From the Epstein Files
item.description: Epstein’s network may not have known everything, but it is hard to deny that many of them knew enough to know better.
item.dc:creator: Ezra Klein
item.media:credit: Ralph Alswang, via Alamy

item.title: We’re All in a Throuple With A.I.
item.description: What happens when the people building a new technology don’t want to use it?
item.dc:creator: Amelia Miller

item.title: Bans on Many CBD Products Loom This Year
item.description: A federal law taking effect in November severely limits the amount of THC, the euphoric cannabis compound, allowed in over-the-counter items. Many groups are fighting back.
item.dc:creator: Jan Hoffman
item.media:credit: Bryan Anselm for The New York Times

item.title: ‘Wuthering Heights’ Gallops Toward $82 Million in Global Ticket Sales
item.description: Warner Bros. spent an estimated $80 million on the R-rated romance, directed by Emerald Fennell, not including hefty marketing costs.
item.dc:creator: Brooks Barnes
item.media:credit: Warner Bros. Pictures
item.media:description: Margot Robbie and Jacob Elordi in “Wuthering Heights.” The director, Emerald Fennell, and Ms. Robbie, a co-producer, went with Warner Bros. because it promised a wide theatrical release.

item.title: In First Public Comments Since Trump’s Racist Video, Obama Laments Lost Decorum
item.description: In a podcast interview, former President Barack Obama did not directly address the video posted by Mr. Trump but denounced a “clown show” on social media.
item.dc:creator: Ali Watkins
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Barack Obama said he thought most Americans were troubled by inflammatory and racist rhetoric in politics.
